channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: International Education: M.I.T. Settles In for Long Haul in Singapore
item.description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has a long-term relationship in Singapore that involves managing five labs with 40 Ph.D. and post-doc researchers.
item.dc:creator: By JANE A. PETERSON
item.media:description: Singapore-M.I.T. Alliance for Research and Technology, or Smart, is a team of professors that manages five laboratories paid for by the Singapore government.

item.title: Doctor Being Treated for Ebola in Omaha Dies
item.description: Dr. Martin Salia, a surgeon who contracted Ebola while working in Sierra Leone, was reportedly in critical condition when he arrived in Nebraska.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Mike Dubose/United Methodist , via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Dr. Martin Salia at United Methodist Kissy Hospital outside Freetown, Sierra Leone.

item.title: Avian Flu Detected in the Netherlands and Britain
item.description: It was not clear if the outbreaks at poultry farms in the two countries were linked, but a British veterinary official said wild birds may have carried the disease.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: People in protective clothing on Monday at a farm in East Yorkshire in the north of England, where a case of bird flu had been found in ducks.

item.title: British and French Militants May Have Been Seen in ISIS Execution Video
item.description: The father of a British militant and a French government minister both raised the possibility that citizens from their countries had been identified.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Pope Francis Confirms He Will Visit the United States Next Year
item.description: The trip, his first to the country as pontiff, will include an international gathering in Philadelphia. Stops in other cities have yet to be announced.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: It was announced that Pope Francis will visit the U.S. in 2015.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Newspaper Calls on Chinese Academics to Cut the Criticism
item.description: A Chinese newspaper’s look into university professors’ criticism of China has triggered an online debate about academic freedom and whether scholars have a patriotic duty to refrain from criticizing the country and its political system.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Keith Bedford for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students listening to a lecture at Sanya College, Hainan Province. A Liaoning Daily investigation concluded that many professors were not supportive enough of China's political system.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Afghans Aren't Giving Up
item.description: Despite the violence and corruption, many say their new president has inspired hope that things will change.
item.dc:creator: By THEODORE L. ELIOT Jr. and KARL F. INDERFURTH

item.title: Burkina Faso Names Ex-Diplomat as Interim Leader
item.description: Michel Kafando, 72, was chosen more than two weeks after the ouster of President Blaise Compaoré, who fled the country in the face of mass protests.
item.dc:creator: By HERVÉ TAOKO and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Kung Tsui-chang on Life as the Heir to Confucius
item.description: Kung Tsui-chang, a 39-year-old businessman in Taiwan who is the 79th-generation direct descendant of Confucius, discusses what it was like growing up in the family of such a famous figure.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Kung Tsui-chang, right, at a ceremony in the Confucius Temple in Taipei, Taiwan, on Sept. 28, 2007, honoring the ancient Chinese philosopher.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Bear That Became the Symbol of a Movement Dies
item.description: Oliver, as the bear was called, was rescued in 2010 by the advocacy group Animals Asia after spending 30 years in bear-bile farms. His dramatic journey to a new life was captured in the documentary “Cages of Shame.”
item.dc:creator: By SHAOJIE HUANG
item.media:description: Oliver was a brown bear who was rescued in 2010 by the advocacy group Animals Asia from a bile farm in the province of Shandong, along with nine other bears.

item.title: Defying Expectations, Japan’s Economy Falls Into Recession
item.description: The country’s gross domestic product shrank by an annualized pace of 1.6 percent in the most recent quarter, threatening a planned tax increase.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: The Shiodome business district in Tokyo. Japan’s gross domestic product fell by an annualized pace of 1.6 percent last quarter, threatening a planned tax increase.

item.title: Iran Nuclear Pact Faces an Array of Opposing Forces
item.description: As negotiations resume this week, there is skepticism among leaders in the United States and many of its allies that a deal can be struck.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER, STEVEN ERLANGER and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Dandano Journal: Fear of Ebola Opens Wary Villages to Outsiders in Guinea
item.description: In Guinea’s Forest Region, villages that have refused outside help to fight the Ebola outbreak are starting to soften their resistance.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: In New Napoleonic Era, His Hats and Stockings Rise to Power
item.description: The prices of the emperor’s belongings have risen relentlessly, including a hat that sold for about $2.4 million at a Paris auction, making it difficult for French museums to compete.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK REEVELL
item.media:description: An 1807 portrait of Napoleon and one of his hats, right, were among the items on sale at a Paris auction over the weekend. They were part of a collection belonging to Monaco’s royal family.

item.title: Favorite Concedes Presidency in Romania
item.description: Prime Minister Victor Ponta conceded Romania’s presidential runoff election late Sunday night to the center-right candidate, Klaus Iohannis, the mayor of the Transylvanian city of Sibiu.
item.dc:creator: By KIT GILLET
item.media:description: Klaus Iohannis in Bucharest, celebrating his victory in the runoff election on Sunday.

item.title: In Public Land Sale, Not All of Spain Is Buying
item.description: There has been a rise in proposed land deals that politicians hope will fill treasuries and that critics see as a possible repeat of a real estate bubble that led to an economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Laura Leon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A reservoir in La Almoraima, an estate that the Spanish government hopes to sell as a potential luxury resort with golf courses, polo grounds and an airport.

item.title: Obama Condemns Islamic State’s Killing of Peter Kassig
item.description: President Obama called the execution of Mr. Kassig, a 26-year-old aid worker, “an act of pure evil” after it was revealed in a video on Sunday.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:credit: Kassig Family, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Peter Kassig with a truck filled with supplies for Syrian refugees in an undated photograph provided by the Kassig family.

item.title: Palestinian Shot by Israeli Troops at Gaza Border
item.description: A spokeswoman for the Israeli hospital where the wounded Palestinian was taken for treatment said he was a 10-year-old boy.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Public Grieving for Pop Singer Is Startling for Iran
item.description: Iranian authorities were caught off guard over the weekend when thousands of people joined spontaneous gatherings around the country to mourn and remember a pop singer who died of cancer at age 30.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: The coffin holding the body of the singer Morteza Pashaei was carried and photographed by a large crowd in Tehran on Sunday.

item.title: Merkel’s Call Befuddles a Punk Rocker
item.description: Andreas Frege of Die Toten Hosen recounts his surprise at an apology from the German chancellor after her party used one of the band's songs in an election night celebration.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Retro Report: ‘Dingo’s Got My Baby’: Lindy Chamberlain's Trial by Media
item.description: Lindy Chamberlain of Australia said that a dingo had entered a tent where her baby lay, and made off with her, but it took 30 years for her to get vindication and closure.
item.dc:creator: By CLYDE HABERMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Fighting Female Genital Mutilation
item.description: In Egypt, a shocking 91 percent of women have been cut.
item.dc:creator: By MONA ELTAHAWY

item.title: Okinawa Voters Replace Governor With Opponent of U.S. Base
item.description: Takeshi Onaga, a former mayor of the capital, unseated Hirokazu Nakaima, who had agreed to move a Marine airfield but keep it on the island.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Takeshi Onaga on Sunday after unseating Hirokazu Nakaima, who had reached a deal on a Marine airfield.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Egypt’s New Police State
item.description: Suppression of freedom of expression under President Sisi is regressing to levels not seen since the Nasser era.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SARA KHORSHID

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In India, Growth Breeds Waste
item.description: Indians are getting dirtier as they get richer, but cleaning up is still someone else's job.
item.dc:creator: By JERRY PINTO
